To determine if we can infer "If Lucy went to the zoo, then Joe went to the park" from the given statement "If Joe went to the park, then Lucy went to the zoo", we need to consider the logical structure of the statements.

The given statement is a conditional statement of the form "If A, then B", where A is "Joe went to the park" and B is "Lucy went to the zoo".

To infer the converse statement "If B, then A", which in this case is "If Lucy went to the zoo, then Joe went to the park", we need to be careful because the truth of the original conditional statement does not necessarily imply the truth of its converse.

In propositional logic, the converse of a true conditional statement is not always true. It is a fallacy known as the "converse error" or "fallacy of the inverse" to assume that the converse is true based solely on the truth of the original conditional statement.

Therefore, we cannot logically infer "If Lucy went to the zoo, then Joe went to the park" from the given statement "If Joe went to the park, then Lucy went to the zoo".
